question_text: In the development of super-knock, how do the dimensionless parameters ξ and ε determine the transition from subsonic deflagration to developing detonation, and what role do hotspot size and excitation time play?
standard_answer: The transition from subsonic deflagration to developing detonation in super-knock is governed by the dimensionless parameters ξ and ε. ξ = a/u represents the inverse ratio of acoustic velocity a to reaction wave velocity u, where u = (∂τi/∂r)^(-1) depends on the ignition delay time (IDT) gradient with distance. Lower ξ values (higher u) favor supersonic autoignitive waves or detonation. ε = r0/(a τe) combines the initial hotspot radius r0 and excitation time τe (the period of significant chemical energy release). As ε increases (larger r0 or shorter τe), the detonation regime widens, making developing detonation more likely. This is because larger hotspots provide more volume for reaction wave acceleration, while shorter excitation times allow rapid energy release that couples with shock waves. For instance, in dimethyl ether/air mixtures at 982 K and 40.5 bar, increasing ε shifts the upper limit ξu upward, expanding the detonation peninsula. Thus, engines with larger thermal inhomogeneities (large r0) and fuels with fast heat release (short τe) are prone to detonation, as the coupling between reaction fronts and pressure waves intensifies, leading to super-knock.
